author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Great Relief
description: Rich Proulx offers a Thursday puzzle to help us chill out.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I had a lot of fun with today’s puzzle. The theme was great, the fill was smooth, and it was overall a very pleasant solving experience. Some highlight entries for me were 22A, 52A and 33D. It’s rare for me, but today I liked everything about the puzzle. I’ll usually have a nitpick, story or gripe to share, but today, it’s just a nice break from the chaos of everyday life. For me, that’s a very special event, and I’m overjoyed by that. Sit back, grab your favorite crossword-appropriate beverage (mine is lavender tea), and enjoy the solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: A Congresswoman’s Story: Raped at 17, ‘I Chose to Have an Abortion’
description: After a legal setback for abortion rights, three Democratic representatives and one Republican shared their personal stories with a House panel.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Cori Bush, a Democrat from Missouri, is known on Capitol Hill as a nurse, a pastor, a Black Lives Matter activist and a member of a “squad” of progressive women lawmakers. On Thursday, she told a House panel that she is also a rape survivor who had an abortion after she was attacked on a church trip when she was 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: With their agenda in the balance, Biden and Pelosi work the Congressional Baseball Game.
description: The game was a respite from partisan division and high drama on Capitol Hill, but talks continued from the stands and dugouts.
content: Lawmakers have been playing a lot of political hardball on Capitol Hill given the multiple crises consuming Washington, but it was actual hardball that drew Democrats and Republicans to Nationals Park on Wednesday night for the annual congressional baseball charity game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Coming Home in the Dark’ Review: No Picnic
description: A family outing attracts mysterious, menacing uninvited guests in this grinding New Zealand thriller.
content: Not infrequently, films set and shot in the Antipodes make a convincing case that one ought to never leave one’s house. Think of the scenarios of “Wake In Fright” (kangaroos and lunatics running amok), “Picnic at Hanging Rock” (girls-school adventurers disappear), “A Cry in the Dark” (dingo, baby). Directed by James Ashcroft from a script he wrote with Eli Kent (based on a short story by Owen Marshall), “Coming Home in the Dark” doesn’t take long in demonstrating that sometimes a day trip to high New Zealand spaces is not worth the views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Consumer Bureau Chief Confirmed in Close Senate Vote
description: The incoming director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, Rohit Chopra, is expected to use his position to rein in financial firms.
content: The Senate confirmed Rohit Chopra on Thursday to run the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in a 50-to-48 party-line vote that overcame objections from Republicans who said he would wield the bureau’s sweeping powers to pursue an anti-business agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: People with disabilities have a tougher time getting Covid vaccines, the C.D.C. reports.
description: It is a stark signal of what the agency’s scientists said was a need for U.S. health officials to remove barriers to access.
content: Americans with a disability were more likely to want coronavirus vaccines but were having a harder time getting them than other people, according to data released on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a stark signal of what the agency’s scientists said was a need for health officials to remove barriers to access.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: New Paramount chairman continues to clean house, showing another executive the door.
description: Paramount parted with its animation president, Mireille Soria, adding to a list of departures.
content: Regime change at Hollywood studios is almost always bloody. A new king or queen arrives and those loyal to the previous court lose their jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Griffin
title: With Big, Bold Art, Sarah Cain Redefines Seriousness in Painting
description: The Los Angeles artist, with her crazy titles and caustic colors, offers “a really provocative combination of pleasure and politics,” says one museum curator.
content: LOS ANGELES — Last summer, the painter Sarah Cain was contemplating the biggest project of her career: a 45-foot-long painting for the East Building Atrium of the National Gallery of Art, in Washington, D.C. Cain, 42, has been making caustically colorful, improvised abstractions since the mid-2000s and had been commissioned to hide construction walls during refurbishment of the atrium’s skylight. Nearby sculptures by Max Ernst, Isamu Noguchi and Richard Serra, too large to relocate, were protected by wooden boxes. Cain was tasked with painting on the boxes, too — each bigger than her studio. (And she needed a title.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Asia surpasses U.S. in vaccinations.
content: In the early months of the pandemic, the Asia-Pacific region was praised for its virus response. Countries had kept the coronavirus under control by masking, testing and keeping borders shut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: ‘Shrinking the Conflict’: What Does Israel’s New Mantra Really Mean?
description: Short of resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, Prime Minister Naftali Bennett wants to “shrink” it. Critics say it’s just a new term for the old policies.
content: JERUSALEM — There’s a new three-word concept taking root in political and diplomatic discourse in Jerusalem: shrinking the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: German Police Arrest 96-Year-Old Nazi Suspect Who Tried to Skip Court
description: The woman, a former secretary in a concentration camp now facing more than 11,000 counts of accessory to murder, failed to show up for a court appearance on Thursday.
content: BERLIN — The 96-year-old woman, a former secretary in a concentration camp, was supposed to appear in court to face charges of being an accessory in the deaths of more than 11,000 people, in what may be one of the last Nazi trials in Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Edward Keating, Times Photographer at Ground Zero, Dies at 65
description: In a risk-taking career, he helped the paper win a Pulitzer for its 9/11 photography and later prompted a debate on journalistic ethics that led to his leaving The Times.
content: Edward Keating, who for more than a month did whatever it took, even disguising himself as a worker, to photograph the wreckage at ground zero after Sept. 11, 2001, contributing to a body of work that brought The New York Times a Pulitzer Prize for photography for its 9/11 coverage, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Breaking Up the Philanthropy ‘Boys Club’
description: This year there has been a surge of charitable giving toward gender equality. Will it stick?
content: — Megan Tompkins-Stange, an assistant professor at the Ford School of Public Policy at the University of Michigan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Guilty’ Review: Dial R for Redemption
description: Jake Gyllenhaal plays an imploding 911 operator in this riveting remake.
content: Whether you favor Gustav Moller’s 2018 Danish drama, “The Guilty,” or the Netflix remake of the same name will depend on whether you prefer your thrillers acoustic or electric, chilly or hot-wired. It will also hinge on your answer to the question, How many close-ups of Jake Gyllenhaal are too many?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: 3 Delicious Reasons to Quick Pickle an Onion
description: This homemade condiment adds a pop of acidity to comforting vegetarian dishes.
content: One of my favorite tiny tasks in the kitchen is to quick pickle some onion or a few shallots. I can scatter it on dishes for days, adding brightness and crunch, and a few drops of the sweet and sour pickling liquid can double as a finish at the table, like a pinch of flaky salt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Huylebroek and Christina Goldbaum
title: As Need in Afghanistan Grows Dire, Aid Groups Plead for Help
description: Health clinics are closing. Temperatures are dipping. Prices are rising. Food and money are scarce. A calamity looms, humanitarian groups warn.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The health care system in Afghanistan is on the brink of collapse, international aid groups warned this week, threatening to deepen the country’s humanitarian crisis just as temperatures begin dropping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Unofficial Start of the Governor’s Race
description: As Gov. Kathy Hochul revs up her fund-raising for next year's primary election, other New York Democrats are also making moves.
content: It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at Gov. Kathy Hochul’s moves to raise money and her potential opponents’ moves to run in the Democratic primary next year. We’ll also look at how rainy September really was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Desmond
title: ‘The Moratorium Saved Us. It Really Did.’
description: With the eviction moratorium over, the road to more opportunity and less inequality runs through affordable housing.
content: Lakia Higbee thinks she got Covid-19 at the Amazon warehouse near Cleveland where she worked as a picker, filling orders for bleach and cat food and anything else customers wanted. She was sent home in November 2020. She was 43 and in decent health, but suddenly she felt she was breathing through a pillow.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Congress, Teen Vaping, October Books: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

author: By Adam Mount and Van Jackson
title: Biden, You Should Be Aware That Your Submarine Deal Has Costs
description: As experts hail the AUKUS agreement, the Biden administration should ensure it does not reflect a self-defeating concept of great power competition.
content: For more than a decade, Washington has struggled to prioritize what it calls great power competition with China — a contest for military and political dominance. President Biden has been working hard to make the pivot to Asia that his two predecessors never quite managed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruchika Tulshyan
title: Ilhan Omar Is Tackling Colorism. Here’s Why That Matters.
description: A number of initiatives in the congresswoman’s fight against toxic skin-lightening products have passed in the House, efforts she hopes will start changing harmful beauty standards.
content: — Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘What You’ll Remember’
description: What is home when you don’t have a house?
content: “What You’ll Remember” is a 12-minute film that touches on themes of family, inequality and homelessness. This Op-Doc is an intimate letter from Elizabeth Herrera to her four children that she composes after moving her family into their first stable housing after 15 years of homelessness and uncertainty. Reflecting on their lives, struggles and joys, she concludes: “Never forget that home is not a building. Home is where your family and the people you love are.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Will 2024 Be the Year American Democracy Dies?
description: The  Capitol riot has been described as both a bullet dodged and a dress rehearsal for a more successful attack on American elections.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Most African countries missed a target to vaccinate 10 percent of their people.
description: Only nine of 52 African countries met the W.H.O.’s benchmark, as the continent continues to lag behind global coronavirus vaccination rates.
content: JOHANNESBURG — Only nine African countries have met a target of vaccinating 10 percent of their populations against Covid-19 by the end of September, the World Health Organization said on Thursday — a statistic that illustrates how far the continent is lagging behind global vaccination rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sudmyer
title: ‘The Found Project’: How We Built Community With the Coming of Age Unit
description: Two schools adapted The Learning Network’s multimedia project to welcome students back this fall. Here is how they did it.
content: We opened our inaugural Coming of Age contest back in September 2020 to offer teenagers a creative outlet for reflecting on that tumultuous year. Over 5,500 participated, and we chose 245 finalists. In March, The Times published this collection of winning work, and last week we published another collection featuring 20 more pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: Yale Says Its Vinland Map, Once Called a Medieval Treasure, Is Fake
description: For decades, researchers at Yale and elsewhere have questioned the authenticity of a map that seemed to reflect Viking travels to North America. The school now says the case is closed.
content: Doubts crept in around Greenland, which looked so good it was frankly suspicious, and questions soon spread all over the map: about the wormholes, the handwriting and, most important, the weirdly crumbling ink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shirley Ngozi Nwangwa
title: The Many Layers of Lorna Simpson
description: With her incisive, boundary-breaking works, the multidisciplinary artist has been exploring the nature of identity, and challenging assumptions about art-making, since the 1980s.
content: In January, the artist Lorna Simpson awed readers of Essence magazine with collages featuring photographs of that month’s cover star, Rihanna. The work was a continuation of Simpson’s ongoing “Earth & Sky” series, in which she replaces the hairdos of Black women in vintage advertisements with decoupaged images of precious metals and cosmic matter, challenging notions that our hair is anything less than sublime. The Rihanna collages spanned a dozen of the issue’s pages, in addition to the cover, and in each portrait the artist superimposed photographs she took of the singer over archival images sourced from The Associated Press, decades-old Ebony magazines and even 19th-century geological lithographs. In one work, Rihanna towers over an entire cityscape, larger than life (on set, Simpson directed her to walk and pose as if she were a giant); the contrasting scales of the background and foreground cast the singer in a different light than that in which she is typically portrayed — less musician or paparazzi subject, more mythical being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: In Deepest Mendocino, Rebuilding a Life in Wine
description: Wells Guthrie made fine wine, but financial challenges diverted his attention. Now he’s got a new label and a second chance, without distractions.
content: BOONVILLE, Calif. — This little town in the Anderson Valley of Mendocino County seems isolated enough. It’s a 40-minute drive west of the nearest major highway, mostly on the winding, two-lane Route 128, and it’s barely on the grid. But Wells Guthrie was looking for something even more secluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Ladies and Gentlemen, Daniel Craig
description: At long last, the star of the James Bond franchise bids farewell to 007 with “No Time to Die” (and learns for the first time about his life as an internet meme).
content: More than a year and a half ago, Daniel Craig and I met at the Museum of Modern Art to talk about his final James Bond movie, “No Time to Die,” and bid farewell to that suave superspy he’d been playing since 2006.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Adam Goldman
title: Trump Server Mystery Produces Fresh Conflict
description: A recent indictment suggested that researchers who found strange internet links between a Russian bank and the Trump Organization did not really believe their own work. They are pushing back.
content: WASHINGTON — The charge was narrow: John H. Durham, the special counsel appointed by the Trump administration to scour the Russia investigation, indicted a cybersecurity lawyer this month on a single count of lying to the F.B.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: In ‘Never Let Go,’ a Solo Performer’s Heart Goes On
description: Michael Kinnan’s sendup of “Titanic” explores the liminal space between tribute and affectionate satire.
content: Michael Kinnan’s “Never Let Go” is a one-man stage version of “Titanic.” That would be enough to persuade a lot of people to head to the Brick Theater, the adventurous Williamsburg black box where the show opened this week. Just as many might shrug in reflexive disdain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Andrew Yang Is Back for a Third Round
description: Can he end America’s two-party system?
content: Andrew Yang failed in his campaigns for president of the United States and mayor of New York City, but that has not stopped him from trying to disrupt the political status quo with a new party, which he has named “Forward.” This time, the candidate known for evangelizing universal basic income, or U.B.I., is championing ideas like open primaries and rank-choice voting (which, incidentally, was the voting system used in the mayoral race he lost). But critics are skeptical that he needs to work outside the two-party system to accomplish these goals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: She Was Training for a Marathon. Suddenly, She Could Barely Walk.
description: What could cause so sudden a decline?
content: The 47-year-old woman lay in bed, exhausted and in pain. Her longtime partner lay next to her, anxious to do anything to help her feel better. Suddenly her right leg jerked and jumped as if possessed by some demon spirit — the movement was fast and erratic and lasted less than five seconds. “What was that?” her partner asked, amazed and worried. Then it happened again. And again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: As Dutch Prime Minister Gets Extra Security, Fears Focus on Drug Gangs
description: Signs of concern for the country’s leader have rattled many in the Netherlands, but experts are split on whether criminal organizations there would really risk targeting politicians.
content: THE HAGUE — For years, Prime Minister Mark Rutte of the Netherlands has cycled or walked to his city-center office, commuting to work like millions of other Dutch people, unencumbered by the large security details that surround other world leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Rick Gladstone
title: Ethiopia Plans to Expel U.N. Officials Leading Aid Response in Tigray
description: The move came days after the U.N. aid chief accused Ethiopia of mounting an aid blockade that is pushing the region into famine.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Ethiopia ordered the expulsion of seven senior United Nations officials on Thursday, two days after the U.N.’s aid chief warned that northern Ethiopia is sliding into famine because the government is blocking aid deliveries to the region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: “Alice Neel: The Early Years”; Diane Simpson’s enigmatic sculptures; and 17 artists explore the concept of space in “Convergent Evolutions.”
content: This year’s enormous Alice Neel show at the Met deserved its acclaim. But it included such a wealth of Neel’s mature portraits — humane figures often surrounded by blue lines — that it was hard not to see her earlier work as a transitional phase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: French and Russian Art on a ‘War and Peace’ Scale
description: The Russian Revolution split the Morozov collection, but a colossal diplomatic effort has brought it back together in Paris. This exhibition is legitimately historic.
content: PARIS — Sometimes you yearn for the beauty of small things: the haiku, the string quartet, the miniature engraving. And then other times, tovarishch, you need your beauty as big as the motherland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Day
title: What’s next? A hearing will be held on Nov. 12 to determine if the conservatorship should end.
description: Britney Spears’s lawyer asked the judge to wait to discuss terminating the arrangement so he could further investigate James P. Spears’s conduct.
content: The court set a hearing for Nov. 12 to decide whether to terminate altogether the conservatorship that has dominated Britney Spears’s life for 13 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Stocks fall, swelling September’s losses.
description: The S&P 500 ended the month down 4.8 percent.
content: A long list of worries caught up with Wall Street in September, the stock market’s worst month since the early days of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Of Vaccine Mandates and Facing Reality
description: Many Americans said they'd quit if required to take their shots. Luckily they didn't.
content: Three weeks ago President Biden announced plans to require Covid-19 vaccinations — or, in some cases, weekly testing as an alternative — for most U.S. workers. There were immediate predictions that the move would backfire, that it would only stiffen vaccine resistance. Indeed, some surveys suggested that as many as half of unvaccinated workers would quit their jobs rather than take their shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: More U.S. parents are willing to vaccinate their children, a survey finds.
description: The shift occurred as the schools reopened amid the Delta variant wave. But the share of parents who were adamantly opposed has barely budged.
content: A new survey found that more parents were willing to vaccinate their children in mid-September than were willing to do so in July, a shift that coincided with schools reopening in the middle of a wave of hospitalizations and deaths caused by the highly contagious Delta.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Is Your Reaction to the State of Abortion Rights in 2021?
description: Recent judicial decisions restricted abortion rights in Texas and expanded them in Mexico. What do these developments mean to you?
content: Please Note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our Student Opinion questions and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on NYTimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only forum that explicitly invites the voices of young people.

title: There’s Nothing to Like in Facebook’s Plans to Hook Our Kids
description: Getting children hooked on social media is a bad idea.
content: Facebook was on Capitol Hill on Thursday to receive its semiregular scolding from Congress about how its services are bad for America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: British program to cover pay ends after subsidizing nearly 12 million jobs.
description: But with a challenging winter ahead, the government has announced a new fund to help households pay for essentials like food and utility bills.
content: After 18 months during which it subsidized 11.6 million jobs, Britain’s government-funded furlough program ended on Thursday, along with some other pandemic relief measures. While it marked another milestone in Britain’s efforts to put the pandemic in the past, the country is experiencing a slowing economic recovery and increasingly severe supply chain disruptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: E.U. nations risk a new virus surge if they ease restrictions now, health officials warn.
description: Not enough people in the bloc have been fully vaccinated to keep the coronavirus from flaring up again, the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control said.
content: There is a high risk of a surge in new coronavirus cases and deaths in European countries with insufficient vaccination coverage if they relax Covid-19 restrictions in the next few weeks, according to a new report by the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Environment Affects Baseball. These Players Want to Help.
description: Beach cleanups, plastic reduction, rethinking travel: A group of major leaguers is pushing back in a wasteful sport.
content: Flying all over North America every week is part of being a major leaguer. The Milwaukee Brewers, for instance, traveled as far away as San Diego and Miami as part of their 162-game regular season this year. Now multiply that by 30 teams across Major League Baseball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Old Henry’ Review: Can’t Keep Him Down on the Farm
description: Starring Tim Blake Nelson, the film tips its hat to classic westerns, even if it gets caught in their shadows.
content: “Old Henry” makes a solid, honorable go of proving once again that the foursquare western isn’t dead, though in paying homage to its forebears, it inevitably stands in their very long shadows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: In Your Facebook Feed: Oil Industry Pushback Against Biden Climate Plans
description: The messages take aim at Democrats by name as part of a broad effort to undermine landmark climate legislation that now hangs in the balance in Congress.
content: The ads appear on Facebook millions of times a week. They take aim at vulnerable Democrats in Congress by name, warning that the $3.5 trillion budget bill — one of the Biden administration’s biggest efforts to pass meaningful climate policy — will wreck the United States economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Kendrick Lamar, Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg to Share Super Bowl Halftime
description: The N.F.L. announced the three Southern California natives will share billing with Mary J. Blige and Eminem at Super Bowl LVI in Los Angeles.
content: The N.F.L. announced Thursday that five performers would share headlining duties at the Super Bowl, with a distinct nod to West Coast hip-hop given the game’s location at SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, Calif. Three Southern California natives and rap titans — Dr. Dre, Snoop Dogg and Kendrick Lamar — will take the stage alongside Mary J. Blige and Eminem during the halftime show scheduled for Feb. 13, 2022. The game will air on NBC.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Asia is speeding ahead on vaccinations.
content: For months, the Asia-Pacific region struggled to get its Covid vaccination campaigns off the ground. But now, several countries in the region are speeding ahead and some have even pulled ahead of the U.S.

content: The Biden administration released a rule Thursday that addresses one of the most fought-over provisions of a coming ban on surprise medical bills.

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jonathan Weisman
title: Pelosi delays a vote on the bipartisan infrastructure bill amid a stalemate among Democrats.
description: The House speaker reversed herself late in the day, after having repeatedly insisted the vote would come on Thursday. Supporters of the bill insisted it was only a temporary setback.
content: President Biden’s trillion-dollar bipartisan infrastructure plan suffered a significant setback late Thursday night when House Democratic leaders, short of support amid a liberal revolt, put off a planned vote on a crucial piece of their domestic agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Chicago’s brawny tabloid, The Sun-Times, may join a nonprofit group.
description: A deal that is in the works would merge the newspaper, the onetime home of Roger Ebert, with Chicago Public Media.
content: Chicago’s brawny tabloid has entered into a merger agreement with the nonprofit organization behind the public radio show “This American Life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Janet Yellen says she supports eliminating the debt limit.
description: “I believe it is very destructive to put the president and myself, as Treasury secretary, in a situation where we might be unable to pay the bills that result from those past decisions,” Ms. Yellen said Thursday.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Thursday that the statutory debt limit should be abolished, arguing that the borrowing cap is “destructive” and poses unnecessary risks to the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Why Families of Missing Women Often Must Lead the Search Themselves
description: The news media was fascinated with the disappearance of Gabrielle Petito. But the families of many women who go missing, especially women of color, struggle for attention.
content: NORTH MIAMI, Fla. — Enrique Gonzalez has become a familiar fixture outside the Publix supermarket in North Miami, where he stops by every evening with a stack of missing person fliers emblazoned with his 13-year-old daughter’s photograph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear Ted Cruz’s Campaign Finance Challenge
description: The justices will also consider a dispute over whether Boston was entitled to turn down a private group’s request to raise a Christian flag in front of its City Hall.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday agreed to hear a challenge to a federal campaign finance law brought by Senator Ted Cruz, Republican of Texas, and a dispute over whether Boston must allow a private group to raise a flag bearing a cross in front of its City Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: The I Survived Series is a Survivor on the Best-Seller List
description: In Lauren Tarshis’ books, the struggle is real — and young readers can’t get enough of these stories of war, wildfire, tornadoes and volcanoes.
content: EYEWITNESS At the peak of the pandemic, when I was short on reassurance, I advised my kids to write about what was happening. The only thing I knew for sure, I explained, was that their grandchildren would want to hear about what it was like to live through this time. Let’s just say that the pens weren’t exactly flying out of the mug in our kitchen, and no one was stealing my laptop charger to fire up Google Docs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Ozy Built a TV Show on a False Claim, Says Its Former Producer
description: Producers say they were led to believe they were making a talk show for A&E, which said no to the program. “You are playing a dangerous game with the truth,” the top producer wrote in his resignation email.
content: By the summer of 2020, Brad Bessey was winding down a long career in television, one that included two daytime Emmy Awards and stints as an executive producer at “Entertainment Tonight” and “The Talk.” He was also, like many Americans in the summer of Covid and George Floyd, eager to make a meaningful social contribution. So when his agent approached him about working for a talk show that would go deep on important social questions, and whose host wanted to bring the country together, he jumped at it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Warby Parker and the Spirit of Invention
description: Those online eyeglasses and mattress start-ups aren’t tech. But they are innovative.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Super PAC Removes Corey Lewandowski After Sexual Harassment Claim
description: The move came after a donor to former President Donald J. Trump said that Mr. Lewandowski had made unwanted sexual advances and touched her inappropriately.
content: Corey Lewandowski, a longtime political adviser to Donald J. Trump, was removed on Wednesday from his role overseeing a super PAC supporting the former president after a donor accused him of making unwanted sexual advances and touching her inappropriately at a dinner in Las Vegas on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Vaccine mandates complicate hospital staffing woes in Wyoming.
description: Administrators face “a delicate balancing act” in a state where hospitals are crowded, workers are scarce and vaccine resistance is widespread.
content: The coronavirus is raging in the northern states of the Mountain West, especially Wyoming, where the Delta variant is tearing through one of the least vaccinated areas in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By José María León Cabrera
title: Police Storm Ecuador Prison Where More Than 100 Inmates Died
description: The officers entered the prison after two days in which gangs connected to criminal drug cartels battled for dominance inside the prison system.
content: QUITO, Ecuador — Hundreds of police officers have entered an Ecuadorean prison where more than 100 inmates died this week, officials said early Thursday, with officials seeking to take back control of the penitentiary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: The Senate rejects a Republican bid to curtail help for Afghans who were evacuated during the U.S. withdrawal.
description: The amendment by Senator Tom Cotton would have cut off aid by the end of March 2023.
content: The Senate on Thursday rejected a Republican effort to use a spending bill needed to keep the government open past midnight to curtail assistance to Afghans who were quickly evacuated to the United States as American troops withdrew from their country last month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Albums to Hear Right Now
description: Haydn piano sonatas, a Shostakovich explosion and the fantastical opera “Sweet Land” are among the highlights.
content: Not all that long ago was a drearier time, when Haydn’s piano sonatas were taken less seriously than those of Mozart and Beethoven. That’s certainly not the case now, at least on record. Marc-André Hamelin brought out a wonderful selection on Hyperion around a decade ago, his brilliance tempered with elegance; Jean-Efflam Bavouzet’s ongoing survey on Chandos is one of the glories of the 21st-century record industry, nine volumes and counting of playing that is poised and polished, as well as ideally flamboyant and aptly witty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: ‘Mandates Are Working’: Employer Ultimatums Lift Vaccination Rates, So Far
description: In California and New York, where mandates for health care workers have gone into effect, many are complying.
content: SACRAMENTO — As California’s requirement that all health care workers be vaccinated against the coronavirus took effect on Thursday, major health systems reported that the mandate had helped boost their vaccination rates to 90 percent or higher. In New York, another mandate that began this week compelled thousands of hospital and nursing home workers to get shots. And at several major corporations, executives reported surges in vaccination rates after adding their own requirements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee, Damien Cave and Ben Dooley
title: How Asia, Once a Vaccination Laggard, Is Revving Up Inoculations
description: Several countries are now on track to surpass the United States in fully vaccinating their populations, lifting hopes of a more permanent return to normality.
content: SINGAPORE — As the United States and Europe ramped up their Covid-19 vaccination programs, the Asia-Pacific region, once lauded for its pandemic response, struggled to get them off the ground. Now, many of those laggards are speeding ahead, lifting hopes of a return to normality in nations resigned to repeated lockdowns and onerous restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy Shoes
description: A new designer at an old house brings wildflowers to Paris Fashion Week.
content: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. So as part of a new series, Wow Moment, we’ll spotlight things we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: The Best Places to Have Babies
description: A new study compares health care costs, accessibility to care, and baby- and family-friendliness in the 50 states and Washington, D.C.
content: There are many factors to consider when choosing a place to live — things like job opportunities, living costs and local politics. But people who are thinking about starting a family have a whole other set of details to mull, many of which are addressed in a new study by WalletHub. The analysis weighed 31 metrics across three categories in each of the 50 states and Washington, D.C., to determine the best and worst places in the United States to have a baby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘The Addams Family 2’ Review: Wednesday Goes West
description: America’s creepiest family takes a road trip in this animated sequel, though their antics are far more kooky than spooky.
content: In 2019, the Addams family returned to the big screen for the first time since the 1990s, this time in animated form. The macabre clan, directly styled after Charles Addams’s original New Yorker cartoon characters and voiced by a star-studded cast, railed against normalcy and blew up a lot of stuff. Now, in a new sequel, they’re taking that show on the road. Like it’s predecessor, “The Addams Family 2” is more kooky than spooky, offering much more to young children than it may to the adults accompanying them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After E.U. Exit, Loss of Drivers Hits U.K. Hard
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 30, 2021.
content: “They’re thinking, ‘Why should I drive a 44,000-liter bomb around, when I can get the same money for delivering boxes of crisps into the supermarket?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Channels Willy Wonka to Explain Congress
description: The “Late Show” host broke into song to tell viewers about budget reconciliation and other works of “legislative wonder.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Alyssa Lukpat
title: Gunman in California Synagogue Shooting Is Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: In a plea deal that spared him the death penalty, John T. Earnest had admitted to killing a woman and injuring three others at a synagogue on the last day of Passover in 2019.
content: The man who opened fire in a synagogue north of San Diego in 2019, killing a 60-year-old woman and injuring three others during the Jewish holiday of Passover, was sentenced on Thursday to life in prison without the possibility of parole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: How Tyson’s Vaccine Mandate Is Working
description: Two months after introducing a pioneering coronavirus vaccine requirement for all of its workers, the food-processing giant details its progress.
content: On Aug. 3, Tyson Foods announced it would require coronavirus vaccines for all 120,000 of its employees in the U.S. The move was notable because it included the meat-processing firm’s frontline workers at a time when corporate mandates mostly applied only to office workers. DealBook spoke with Dr. Claudia Coplein, Tyson’s chief medical officer, about the results of its decision nearly two months later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Facebook Grilled by Senators Over Its Effect on Children
description: The company faces accusations that it hid research showing the mental and emotional harm that Instagram, its photo-sharing app, has on teenagers.
content: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers took sharp aim at Facebook on Thursday, harshly questioning one of its executives about Instagram’s effect on teenagers, in a Senate hearing that illuminated the growing bipartisan frustrations and concerns with the social media giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: It’s Up, and It’s … Good?: Why Teams Don’t Try More Long Field Goals
description: Kickers, kicking techniques and playing conditions have all improved, but the downsides of coming up short still discourage coaches from challenging the record.
content: When Tom Dempsey walloped a 63-yard field goal for the New Orleans Saints in 1970, it might have ushered in a new era of long kicks. Instead, it was an anomaly, so much so that it took decades for another kicker to match it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Stop and Go’ Review: Pandemic Aside, Girls Just Want to Have Fun
description: This trite Covid-19-era comedy follows a pair of kooky sisters on a cross-country mission to save their grandmother from a nursing home overrun with cases.
content: Frankly, a “Covid-era comedy” reads like a threat to this critic, though maybe others will get more mileage out of social distancing gags circa March 2020, when the mere thought of public spaces sent shivers down the spine. The pandemic is hardly behind us, yet “Stop and Go,” starring and written by Whitney Call and Mallory Everton, formerly of the sketch comedy show Studio C, feels awfully outdated. Many of us may have doused our things in comical amounts of disinfectant and flown into frenzies by mere throat tickles, but the relatability factor is redundant at this point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Thomas
title: Thierry Mugler Returns to Paris With ‘Couturissime’
description: The Musée des Arts Décoratifs is the latest stop for an exhibition of more than 150 of the designer’s eye-popping creations.
content: It’s been 20 years since Thierry Mugler, the enfant terrible of 1980s and ’90s Paris fashion who turned fashion shows into rock events, stepped down from his namesake company. But he didn’t retire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Lithuania vs. China: A Baltic Minnow Defies a Rising Superpower
description: Lithuania has enraged China by advising officials to scrap Chinese phones that it says contain censorship software, while cozying up to Taiwan and quitting a Chinese-led regional forum.
content: VILNIUS, Lithuania — It was never a secret that China tightly controls what its people can read and write on their cellphones. But it came as a shock to officials in Lithuania when they discovered that a popular Chinese-made handset sold in the Baltic nation had a hidden though dormant feature: a censorship registry of 449 terms banned by the Chinese Communist Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: How Do You Solve ‘The Problem With Jon Stewart’?
description: The host’s biweekly issues-comedy show has good intentions, and sometimes good jokes.
content: Calling your new public-affairs-comedy show “The Problem With Jon Stewart” is a provocation and a pre-emption. It sounds like the title of a think-piece that could have been written at any point over the last two decades, accusing the one-time “Daily Show” host of false equivalence, or partisanship, or naïveté.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Oct. 6, 2021
description: What do you notice and wonder about Sunisa Lee’s Olympic balance beam routine?
content: This composite photograph of Sunisa Lee, a U.S. gymnast, shows the end of her winning routine on the balance beam at this summer’s Olympics in Tokyo. Though this is a photograph, it can be interpreted as a graph showing her position over time. The photos in this composite graphic were shot at approximately equal time intervals. How do the positions of one part of her body compare over time? Based on this data, if you had the data from photos of her other balance beam performances or those of her competitors, you could compare them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Miriam Toews Gets Nervous When People Assume She’s Read the Classics
description: “I literally start to sweat. I’ll rush home to have another go at ‘The Golden Bowl,’ or whatever.”
content: “I literally start to sweat,” says the novelist Miriam Toews, whose latest book is “Fight Night.” “I’ll rush home to have another go at ‘The Golden Bowl,’ or whatever.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Manchin says he’ll support a $1.5 trillion social safety net bill, $2 trillion less than Biden’s sweeping plan.
description: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a centrist Democrat, said Thursday that he could not support a social safety net bill of more than $1.5 trillion, less than half the size of the package that President Biden and Democratic leaders have been trying to push through Congress.
content: Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a centrist Democrat, said Thursday that he could not support a social safety net bill of more than $1.5 trillion, less than half the size of the package that President Biden and Democratic leaders have been trying to push through Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: There’s a Bipartisan Voting Rights Bill. Yes, Really.
description: The Native American Voting Rights Act is a bill that lawmakers might — might! — be able to agree on.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Lawmakers Back Changes at C.I.A. for Handling Mystery Health Episodes
description: Legislation approved by a House committee would also offer intelligence officials medical scans before transfer overseas to better diagnose Havana syndrome injuries.
content: WASHINGTON — The House Intelligence Committee approved a bipartisan proposal on Thursday to provide additional resources to help find the cause of Havana syndrome illnesses and take steps to review the C.I.A.’s handling of the mysterious episodes that have injured more than 200 government officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Right to Health
description: Immunization mandates aren’t new. One helped win the American Revolution.
content: The United States owes its existence as a nation partly to an immunization mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Bazelon
title: Divorce Can Be an Act of Radical Self-Love
description: I didn’t divorce my husband because I didn’t love him. I divorced my husband because I loved myself more.
content: I used to believe that divorce is a terrible thing, particularly when children are involved. Growing up, I absorbed cultural tropes about absent fathers in efficiency apartments, mothers struggling to support themselves, and awful stepparents and unwanted stepsiblings. To this day, divorce is portrayed as precarious and grim. Parents whose marriages break apart are made to feel they have failed catastrophically. Divorce is shameful, traumatic and Bad For The Kids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Shteir
title: Revisiting a Post-Apocalyptic Play in the Pandemic
description: Anne Washburn’s phantasmagoric “Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play” is getting a timely new run at Theater Wit in Chicago.
content: CHICAGO — One of the most unbearable things about the pandemic is the uncertainty: about what we can and cannot do, and the way our understanding of what is going on gets tangled in conflicting stories or collapses altogether. And then there is the dread about what will happen next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Butcher
title: I Know All Too Well How a Lovely Relationship Can Descend Into Abuse
description: Intimate partner violence is epidemic in this country. We just don’t always hear about it.
content: Like much of America, I spent the past two weeks closely monitoring the case of Gabrielle Petito, 22, who left home with a van and aspirations of seeing America but also a partner who was later seen slapping and hitting her, according to a 911 caller. On police body camera footage taken one month before she was reported missing, Ms. Petito says that Brian Laundrie, her fiancé, grabbed her by her chin, and his face appears scratched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Venom: Let There Be Carnage’ Review: The One-Man Odd Couple Returns
description: Starring Tom Hardy, this superhero sequel turns into a slapstick blood bath about two threesomes both in desperate need of throuples therapy.
content: Once, thespians hungered to play Othello. For Tom Hardy, an actor devoted to the art of emoting behind a mask (and eight figures of special effects), there is Venom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rita Dove and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: Postlude
description: A bounty of clarity in the poetry of Rita Dove.
content: In a poem of mine, I once borrowed the lines “If you can’t be free, be a mystery” from Rita Dove’s “Canary.” Using the lines, I possessed, for a moment, a rare kind of clarity. You gotta know who you are and who people imagine you to be, to really be free in this world. This new collection, “Playlist for the Apocalypse,” is a bounty of such moments. Like this one, in “Postlude,” where Dove doesn’t stop at “you prefer me invisible,” but reminds you (America, maybe) that “this is my business.” Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Police Officer Sentenced to Life in Prison for Murder of Sarah Everard
description: The extent to which Ms. Everard’s attacker wielded his powers as a police officer in the horrific attack has prompted a wave of new calls for reform in the London police department.
content: LONDON — The police officer who abducted, raped and murdered Sarah Everard was sentenced on Thursday to life in prison by Britain’s top criminal court, after two days of hearings that reignited outrage at the way London’s police department handles cases involving violence against women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Travel back to the ’90s with a beloved children’s show and one of TV’s greatest comedies.
content: This is the web version of our Watching newsletter, in which Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations like these every Monday and Friday. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for Watching here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judge John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Birthday Traditions
description: A mother tries to impose her iron will of well-wishing on her adult daughter.
content: Abigail writes: During birthdays, my mother makes everyone say nice things about the birthday honoree. I am one of four kids, all with small children. In the middle of feeding toddlers and crying babies, our mother insists on a Meaningful Family Moment. But we feel we can decide if, when and how to say nice things to one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: A study finds no signs of trouble in getting flu and Covid shots at the same time.
description: A British clinical trial, which supports the advice of U.S. health authorities, is welcome news as flu season begins.
content: A British clinical trial found no sign of danger in getting a flu shot and a second dose of a Covid-19 vaccine at the same time, results that support the advice of U.S. health authorities and are welcome news for strained health care workers as flu season hits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Enormous: The Gorge Story’ Review: A Musical Paradise
description: A loving documentary about a Pacific Northwest amphitheater, created by a long-ago natural catastrophe, that is a haven for concertgoers.
content: What’s the ideal place to experience live music? For some, a midsize hall with immaculate acoustics; for others, an intimate nightclub with a well-stocked bar; for others still, a clamorous, sweaty dive. For those who are able to get there, and who have an affinity with its vibe, the Gorge Amphitheater in George, Wash., with its scenic beauty and open-air sonics, is heaven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson and Sian Davey
title: A Ceramist Inspired by Folklore and the British Countryside
description: In Somerset, the artist Prue Piper has spent decades forging connections between her pottery, her garden and the myths entwined with the landscape.
content: FIRST-TIME VISITORS TO the ceramist Prue Piper’s house are typically late, and readily forgiven for it, because the place, a charmingly ramshackle former 19th-century laundry in Somerset, England, nestled among 11 acres of garden, orchard and woodland, is nearly impossible to find. For one, it’s in a village, Marston Bigot, that hardly exists except in name (its growth was stymied in part by the 14th-century bubonic plague). And then there is the driveway, the entrance of which is marked only by a rusted iron sculpture, made by Piper’s adult son Henry, that hides in waist-high overgrowth. The property’s integration into the surrounding patchwork of rolling fields and wild hedgerows is exactly what prompted Piper, 83, and her husband, the artist Edward Piper, to move here in 1967.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Here are the key issues facing Congress today.
description: In a pivotal week, in a make-or-break stretch for President Biden’s domestic agenda, congressional Democrats are trying to assemble a puzzle of four jagged pieces that may or may not fit together.
content: In a pivotal week, in a make-or-break stretch for President Biden’s domestic agenda, congressional Democrats are trying to assemble a puzzle of four jagged pieces that may or may not fit together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden Campaigned as the Anti-Trump. But a Clean Break Is Never Easy.
description: When it comes to policy, the president is finding that it is not always easy to draw a clear line separating himself from his predecessor.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden has been so eager to move past the Trump era that he prefers to call his predecessor “the former guy” rather than utter his name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Alito Responds to Critics of the Supreme Court’s ‘Shadow Docket’
description: In a speech at Notre Dame, the justice addressed recent emergency rulings on abortion, asylum and evictions, saying they followed longstanding procedures.
content: WASHINGTON — In a combative speech on Thursday, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. defended several of the Supreme Court’s recent rulings on what critics call its “shadow docket,” saying the news media had created the impression that “a dangerous cabal is deciding important issues in a novel, secretive, improper way in the middle of the night, hidden from public view.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: The U.S. says Texas’ ban on school mask mandates may violate disabled children’s rights.
description: The Department of Justice filed a court brief saying that the ban runs afoul of federal law if, as parents claim, it is preventing their disabled children from safely attending public schools.
content: The Justice Department signaled its support on Wednesday for the families of children with disabilities in Texas who are suing to overturn Gov. Greg Abbott’s ban on mask mandates in the state’s schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Youth Vaping Declined Sharply for Second Year, New Data Show
description: Now that it has stopped selling most flavored pods, Juul has become far less popular with teens than brands offering disposable fruit- and candy-flavored devices.
content: Teen use of electronic cigarettes fell sharply in 2021, the second consecutive year of big declines, according to the government’s annual National Youth Tobacco Survey.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The Times.
content: Simone de Beauvoir has a new book out, 35 years after her death: The novel “Inseparable” closely follows the true-life story of Beauvoir’s early childhood friendship with the iconoclastic and doomed Élisabeth Lacoin, a.k.a. “Zaza,” who died at the age of 21. It’s a short book that offers a key to some of Beauvoir’s own political engagement and philosophical development, and it’s one of the books we recommend this week. We also like a couple of memoirs, by Kat Chow and the playwright Sarah Ruhl, along with a close look at the murder trial of the Navy SEAL Eddie Gallagher, and new fiction from Maurice Carlos Ruffin and Anthony Doerr (his first novel since the Pulitzer-winning “All the Light We Cannot See”). And a couple of books that might have appealed to Beauvoir herself if she were still on the scene: Randall Kennedy’s essay collection “Say It Loud! On Race, Law, History, and Culture” and Amia Srinivasan’s “The Right to Sex: Feminism in the Twenty-First Century.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: A painter of expatriate life, an online potion boutique — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Answers to Questions About the Texas Abortion Law’
description: Students will learn about a new Texas law that effectively bans abortion, then share their opinions about the status of abortion rights right now.
content: Featured Article: “Answers to Questions About the Texas Abortion Law” by Roni Caryn Rabin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: A 2nd Cuomo Investigation Is Expected to Confirm Harassment Claims
description: The final report, expected in October, could revive calls for lawmakers to impeach Andrew Cuomo, the former governor, to prevent him from running again, though that seems unlikely.
content: In the weeks before and after his resignation as governor, Andrew M. Cuomo defended his behavior, deflected blame and tried to discredit Letitia James, the state attorney general who concluded that he had sexually harassed multiple women while in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Desmond
title: Dasani Showed Us What It’s Like to Grow Up Homeless. She’s Still Struggling.
description: “Invisible Child,” by the New York Times reporter Andrea Elliott, expands on her much-admired 2013 series, following the lives of a New York City child and her family, as they strive to stay together and make ends meet.
content: INVISIBLE CHILD Poverty, Survival and Hope in an American City By Andrea Elliott
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: An Artist’s Portraits, Stitched Together on the Subway
description: After a decade of embroidering portraits of loved ones, LJ Roberts delivers a lesson on queer kinship in a new exhibition at Pioneer Works in Brooklyn.
content: LJ Roberts starts by stitching the faces of friends and lovers, recalling in hand-sewn portraits the contours of a saved photograph or deeply personal memory. For the last decade, the artist has created these pocket-size embroideries during downtime and subway rides around New York. A tapestry of queer and trans history, activism and politics has emerged, defined by the details: handmade protest signs, bumper stickers, pride flags and pet collars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry M. Paulson Jr
title: We’re Living Through One of the Most Explosive Extinction Episodes Ever
description: The growing damage to the world’s biodiversity presents dire risks to human societies.
content: Twin crises afflict the natural world. The first is climate change. Its causes and potentially catastrophic consequences are well known. The second crisis has received much less attention and is less understood but still requires urgent attention by global policymakers. It is the collapse of biodiversity, the sum of all things living on the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: It Shouldn’t Take 50 Meetings to Build Some Apartments
description: How to solve the housing crisis (part 3).
content: Who should be in charge of housing? Should it be local homeowners who organize themselves into neighborhood organizations to protect their interests? How about local elected officials, who presumably were put in office to think about the needs of their constituents, especially when it comes to making sure they actually get to stay in their homes and don’t get displaced by hordes of newcomers? Or should it be the federal government, which, when it has stepped in on housing issues in the past, has done so mostly to protect poor and minority homeowners from housing discrimination?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver and Danya Issawi
title: ‘Finsta,’ Explained
description: What is it, really? And can one commit to ending it?
content: Facebook’s global head of safety, Antigone Davis, faced harsh — and, briefly, existential — questioning on Capitol Hill on Thursday about Instagram’s effect on teenagers, addressing accusations that the app’s parent company, Facebook, had known for years that its photo-sharing app had caused mental and emotional harm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Falling for Figaro’ Review: When the Overtures Are Operatic
description: An American finance executive leaves behind her cushy life in favor of a musical career in this humdrum romance set in the Scottish Highlands.
content: I must admit it’s refreshing to see a plus-size woman not only nab the promotion and the hunky guy, but throw it all away within the first 15 minutes. Unfortunately, my plaudits for “Falling for Figaro” mostly end there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: The Academy Museum Finds Good Intentions in Messy Film History
description: While the cinematic objects on display fascinate, the much-delayed institution opens with an emphasis on diversity and pluralism, not past and present sins.
content: Tucked in the new Academy Museum of Motion Pictures, which opened Thursday in Los Angeles, is a surprisingly modest exhibit of “significant Oscars.” The museum, after all, is the latest venture of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the organization that each year entertains, inflames and invariably stupefies movie lovers of every taste and critical persuasion with that gaudy bacchanalia of self-love known as the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Rifkin
title: John J. Rigas, Cable TV Magnate Who Pillaged His Company, Dies at 96
description: He built Adelphia Communications into a business with 5.5 million customers, then was convicted of stealing hundreds of millions of dollars from it.
content: John J. Rigas, who turned a $300 investment in a local cable television system into the nation’s sixth largest cable company, only to see his empire collapse after he was convicted of looting the business of hundreds of millions of dollars, died on Thursday in Coudersport, Pa. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Scarlett Johansson and Disney Settle Suit Over ‘Black Widow’ Pay
description: Pay for actors is a contentious issue as Hollywood movies are released for streaming at the same time they hit theaters.
content: LOS ANGELES — Scarlett Johansson and Walt Disney Studios reached a settlement on Thursday in a legal dispute involving streaming-era compensation for the superhero film “Black Widow.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Karen Dalton: In My Own Time’ Review: An Elemental Musical Force
description: A documentary chronicles the turbulent life of a singer whose music made a substantial impression on New York’s 1960s folk scene and still resonates today.
content: Musicians working in pop modes often navigate their careers using a combination of talent and calculation. Karen Dalton, a singer and instrumentalist who made a substantial impression on New York’s 1960s folk scene, and whose small body of recorded work moves and inspires listeners to this day, was someone for whom calculation was inconceivable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Shaila Dewan
title: More Than Half of Police Killings Are Mislabeled, New Study Says
description: Researchers comparing information from death certificates with data from organizations that track police killings in the United States identified a startling discrepancy.
content: Police killings in America have been undercounted by more than half over the past four decades, according to a new study that raises pointed questions about racial bias among medical examiners and highlights the lack of reliable national record keeping on what has become a major public health and civil rights issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Carlisle Floyd, Whose Operas Spun Fables of the South, Dies at 95
description: His celebrated works drew from the musical traditions of revival meetings and country hoedowns, telling stories of intolerance.
content: Carlisle Floyd, the composer-librettist whose operas explored the passions and prejudices of the South in lyrical tales that drew on rural fundamentalism, the Great Depression, the aftermath of the Civil War and other regional themes, died on Thursday in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Leader of Prestigious Yale Program Resigns, Citing Donor Pressure
description: The historian Beverly Gage, who has run the Grand Strategy course since 2017, says the university failed to stand up for academic freedom amid inappropriate efforts to influence the curriculum.
content: The Brady-Johnson Program in Grand Strategy is one of Yale University’s most celebrated and prestigious programs. Over the course of a year, it allows a select group of about two dozen students to immerse themselves in classic texts of history and statecraft, while also rubbing shoulders with guest instructors drawn from the worlds of government, politics, military affairs and the media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: This Is Why We Need to Spend $4 Trillion
description: When you’re facing a social crisis it’s time to go big.
content: I’ve spent the last few weeks in a controlled fury — and I’m not normally a fury kind of guy. Joe Biden, Nancy Pelosi and others are trying to pass arguably the most consequential legislative package in a generation, and what did I sense in my recent travels across five states? The same thing I sense in my social media feed and on the various media “most viewed” lists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: How My Desire to Run Again Pushed Me to Walk
description: After recovering from a traumatic brain injury, a writer seeks to reclaim the mental transcendence that comes from running.
content: I only began to understand why I was so stubbornly devoted to running when I couldn’t do it anymore. That’s where I was when I woke up in an emergency room on the morning of April 6, 2020, with a traumatic brain injury sustained during a dumb middle-of-the-night fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Taavo Somer Can Make Anything Cool, Even Golf
description: The creator of Freemans Sporting Club, who helped define the ye olde aesthetic of the early aughts, opens a country club in the Hudson Valley.
content: Without Taavo Somer, the high priest of heritage chic in early 2000s New York, the Strokes generation may never have adopted Paul Bunyan as a style muse, decorated their apartments with cabinets of curiosities, or decided en masse that unkempt beards were suddenly cool for the first time since “Hotel California.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Hope
title: How to Fight Right — in a Pandemic or After
description: When couples aren’t seeing eye to eye — and there seems to be more of these moments than usual lately — there are ways to redirect your energy to fight “well.”
content: Dori Brail says she can tell when a fight is brewing with her wife of three years, Angie Peng. “I can feel it bubbling up,” said Ms. Brail, 41, a social work supervisor at a public defender’s office in New York. “The tone in our voices is different and our body language is stiffer and more defensive. Both of us need space when we’re upset, but at different times.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Thousands of Haitians Are Being Allowed Into the U.S. But What Comes Next?
description: Members of a Haitian church in Philadelphia opened their hearts and pocketbooks to sponsor a family of immigrants. Then came another, and another.
content: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, N.J. — In early May, Rooldy Alexandre, a Haitian American pastor, answered a late-night call from a man speaking Creole who identified himself as Josue Alexis and said he had been following Mr. Alexandre’s sermons online. “Pastor, I just crossed the border with my pregnant wife and young child,” the man said. “Can you help?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: After Mandate, 91% of Tyson Workers Are Vaccinated
description: The company’s vaccine requirement covers all of its 120,000 U.S. employees. Frontline workers have until Nov. 1 to get inoculated.
content: Tyson Foods has reached a 91 percent vaccination rate for its work force, the latest evidence that corporate vaccine mandates can help increase immunizations in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A Decade of Work, a Shocking Accident and a Bevy of Supermodels
description: The Balmain Festival in honor of Olivier Rousteing’s 10th anniversary at the house meant more than anyone could have imagined.
content: PARIS — When Olivier Rousteing took over the house of Balmain 10 years ago, the fashion bookmakers weren’t giving him great odds for success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Run Out of Netflix Shows to Watch? Try These.
description: Fashion week may be back in-person, but not every designer wants to give up the digital approach. Marine Serre, Thebe Magugu, Burberry and Dries Van Noten explore the connection.
content: PARIS — The last year and a half of being stuck to the small screen for work and pleasure, desperate for any new piece of escapism be it blockbuster or art house or glossy series, has to have changed forever our relationship to the moving picture, raising the stakes and the expectations. And if, when fashion first went online, the idea of transforming a show into a video seemed like a potential savior for the industry, it also exposed some of the limits in the fashion imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Sharon Otterman
title: Here’s a rundown of the legal challenges to New York’s vaccine mandate.
description: New York’s mandate that more than 650,000 hospital and nursing home workers be vaccinated against Covid-19 took effect this week, prompting tens of thousands of holdouts to get their first dose. But the mandate has also prompted lawsuits across the state by nurses and others who are seeking exemptions.
content: New York’s mandate that more than 650,000 hospital and nursing home workers be vaccinated against Covid-19 took effect this week, prompting tens of thousands of holdouts to get their first dose. But the mandate has also prompted lawsuits across the state by nurses and others who are seeking exemptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Young Women Set the Tone for a Paris Theater Season
description: The directors staging the most ambitious premieres are all female millennials.
content: PARIS — In March last year, Pauline Bayle’s “Lost Illusions” closed after just two performances, the day before France’s first coronavirus lockdown came into force. Eighteen months later, the Théâtre de la Bastille was chock-full once more for the production’s return to the stage — and the mood in Paris appeared to have finally lifted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Rappers Come Shop for Jewelry. Icebox Turns the Cameras On.
description: An Atlanta store where hip-hop’s big names buy diamond-encrusted watches and chains has become a social media phenomenon by capturing the safe spaces of the rich and flamboyant.
content: ATLANTA — The display cases at the Atlanta jewelry store Icebox teem with Cuban link chains, watches called bustdowns covered edge to edge in diamonds, gold pendants in dozens of designs. It is the ne plus ultra of contemporary hip-hop luxury. And over the last three years, Icebox has built a secondary business atop this phenomenon, starting a YouTube channel filled with videos of rappers coming in to salivate and shop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: belie
description: This word has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Ruth Sullivan, Advocate for People With Autism, Dies at 97
description: After her son was found to be autistic, she started organizations to help children and adults. She also consulted on the making of the movie “Rain Man.”
content: Ruth Sullivan, a public health nurse who became an influential advocate for autistic children and adults after one of her sons was diagnosed with the disorder in the early 1960s, died on Sept. 16 at an assisted-living facility in Huntington, W.Va. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Five Stylish, and Endlessly Versatile, Diver Watches
description: With bands of sporty rubber or modern steel, fall’s water-resistant timepieces easily transition from the sea to the street.
content: Diver watches are meant for, well, diving, and this crop is no exception: All of the timepieces are water-resistant up to at least 100 meters, and most can function at three times that depth. But, in addition to sporty functionality, they also offer style. Tag Heuer’s Aquaracer Professional 300, for instance, has a steel bracelet, and the circular case of Bell & Ross’s BR 03-92 Diver Blue sits atop a square base. These fashion-forward touches lend versatility to the watches, which could easily travel from aquatic expeditions to social engagements back on land. The Louis Vuitton model, which features a rubber strap printed with the brand’s logo, is even named the Tambour Street Diver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Sheera Frenkel
title: Facebook Downplays Internal Research Released on Eve of Hearing
description: The social network published its findings about Instagram’s effect on young users, as senators prepared to question an executive on Thursday.
content: Facebook on Wednesday published two internal research reports about its photo-sharing app, Instagram, and downplayed their conclusions, as the company prepared for two congressional hearings in the next week that are focused on its products’ effects on children’s mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Den of Toys
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times
